cards.title: Condensation Polymerisation
cards.description:
The 'opposite' of condensation reactions are hydrolysis reactions. For the molecule that makes these, take a look at !H1m96Rbif

Condensation reactions are anabolic, endergonic reactions that require energy to function (i.e synthesis of proteins takes energy)

Polymerisation can be remembered through through it's prefix poly - many. Many monomers are joined.

If answering questions about identifying polymers, remember to be specific and identify properties unique to them, for instance, their bonds being peptide bonds for amino acids.

cards.title: Lock and key versus induced fit model
Permeability of phospholipid bilayer
cards.description: Seem to struggle remembering the word 'protein channel'. Also, make sure you nail the whole polar=water soluble=can't diffuse through the membrane.

cards.description: #error: The right most box labelled 'receptor' should be labeled 'response'

pages.text:
- When identifying what something is based on an image, substantiate your answer with evidence based on theory. For instance, in this question, it was not enough to say that is is a carbohydrate molecules, I also needed to support that claim with theory based on the diagram. For instance, I could have included that the bonds are peptides (*CHECK*) or that there is no (*CHECK*) atoms...


- Nail your hypothesis before a SAC, and don't change it on a whim because you think you're adding something that you'd forgotten. In this question, I stated that once the protein denatured, no colour change would be visible, which is false because not all of the protein would denature, so some colour change would still be visible. I would have been more correct stating simply "...until a certain point"


- This question based on graphs should have been easy if I had reconsidered the graphs based on what I did know, rather than worrying too much about being confused. I knew that if there was more energy after a reaction than before, it must have lost energy and thus could have connected it with vocabulary definitions. - Don't leave questions blank. If you mean to come back to something, make sure you do. In this case, I could have gotten some small marks here, but instead was caught on a larger mark but more difficult question at the end of the SAC, and thus didn't have time to come back and get easy marks.
- Make notes and understand the details of the complement system: Edrolo complement system

ops.insert: The independent variable is removed from the experiment. This ensures that the dependent variable is controlled only by the influence of the dependent variable, and not other, random environmental factors.

Controlled by the experimenter, and typically the x axis of graphs.
Dependent variable
Dependent on the independent variable, and typically the y axis of graphs.

As (IV) (IV Unit) (increases/decreases/is changed to etc), the (DV) (DV Unit) will (increase/decrease/become/etc)
Conclusion
Never write vague statements, always be specific

If there is a picture, diagram or table, etc, it's not there to look pretty. Refer to it in our answers. Only sometimes will it say 'refer to the diagram'. Even if it is just a generic picture of a protein and is asking about quaternary structure, refer to number of polypeptides in depicted protein.
If there is a graph, use the data to use your point. "It reached a maximum of six PH"
Use a ruler with graphs and be neat.
Make sure you know the question verbs. Explain, justify, describe, compare, define, etc.
movement of input elements to output elements.
Useful for questions relating to putting in 'radioactive oxygen and tracing to outputs'. Just
where they move can be easier than trying to understand question's wording.

pages.text:
Components/terms

Intergral/Peripheral

  • Intergral proteins are permanent
  • Peripheral proteins are temporary

Transmembrane

  • Crossing across the membrane (ie. reaching both sides.)



Permeability

ops.insert: Water, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids, carbohydrates
There are several ways of expressing a molecules structural formulas. Straight form, ring form, ball and stick model, space filling model
Bonds between dfferent molecules are called hydrogen bonds
A water molecule has a slight positive charge on the hydrogens and a slight negative charge on the oxygen.
Hydrogen bonding is also important in the formation of proteins and nucelic acids, eg - DNA
Determine the characteristics and chemical reactivity of molecules. Hydroxyl, Carbonyl, Carboxyl, Amino, Sulgydryl, Phosphate, etc.
Need to recognise amino groups and where they are attached
Organic molecules containing amino groups are called amines. Amines are weak bases. The amino group is common to all amino acids, which are in turn the building blocks of proteins.
Water provides an environment in which metabolic reactions can take place.
Water has a dipole nature, meaning it has two charges. It is polar.
Water has many properties which are critical for life.
Colourless with a high transmission of visible light
Strong cohesive properties and high tensile strength
Many substances can dissolve in water, it is classifies as a univeral solvent.
High latent heat of fusion, significant amounts of energy are required before water will change state
Has high latent heat of vaporization.
High specific heat capacity, can absorb heat energy.
Latent heat - Energy released or absorbed by a body during a constant temperature process, while it is changing state.
Family of organic molecules made up of carbon, hydrgogen and oxygen.
Some small, simple, others long, forming polymoers
Simple carbohydrates are generally called sugars. The most common arrangements found in sugar
Pentose, five side sugar. Ribose and deoxyribose.
Naturally form rings rather than straight chain structures
Important as both energy storage molecules asnd as the structural elements inc ells and tissues
The structure is closely related to their function
Sugars (mono, di, tri saccharides) play a central role in energy storage
Carbohydrates are the major component of most plants, (60-90% dry weight)
Used as food, fuel, weaving cloth and for building materials (grass as thatch, etc)
Primary energy source for cellular metabolism
Generally contain between three and seven carbon atoms in their carbon chains, 6C hexose sugar most common
Reducing sugars, meaning they can participate in reduction reactions.
Double sugar molecules joined with a glyosidic bond
Used as energy sources and as building blocks for larger molecules
The type of disaccharide formed depends on the monomers involved and whether they are in their alpha or beta form
Only a few, like lactose, are classified as reducing sugars.
When alpha glucose molecules join they form starch
When beta glucose molecules join together they form cellulose
They differ only in the direction that the OH group is pointing
Chemical breakdown of a compound due to reaction with water
Cellulose is a glucose polymer. Structural material in plant
Made up of chains of beta glucose molecules held together
Parallel chains are cross linked by drogen bonds to form bundles with microfibrils
Form of energy storage in animals
Absorbed into bloodstream with digestions of carbohydrates
Carried to the liver and then to all cells
If there is excess it is converted to glyogen byh the liver for storage (100g)
Polymer of glucose, made up of long chains of alpha glucose molecules.
Contains a mixture of amylose and amylopectin
Starch is an energy storage molecules in plants
Found cconcentrated in insoluble starch granules within plant cells
Easily hydralised to glucose when required
Chitin is a tough modified polysaccharide made up of chains of beta glucose molecules
Similar to cellulose but Oh group at carbon atom 2 is replaced bitin forms bundles of long parallel chainsy a nitrogen containing group
Monosaccharides are joined together to form disaccharides and polysaccharides
Water is released in the process
Energy is supplied by nucleotide sugar such as ADP
Compound sugars can be broken down with water
Group of organic compunds. (Oily, greasy, waxy)
Much smaller proportion of oxygen than carbohdrates
Relatively insoluble inw ater, tend of be hydrophobic
Lipdids are soluble in organic solvents such as ethanol
Many functions (fuels, hormones, structural components of membranes)
Twice as much energy as carbohydrates
Not macromolecules, byh because of hydrophobic properties, aggrgate into globules
Provide waterproofing in plants and animals
Absorbs shocks (organs are prone to bumps and shocks). Suchioned with fat
Difference is physical state at 20 degrees
Saturated versus unsaturated (number of hydrogens) saturated = maximum hydrogens
Saturated forms straight chains. All single bonds.
Unsaturated contain some carbon atoms that are double bonded with each other
Kinks in molecule cause them to be liquid
A glycerol molecule, two fatty acid chains, and a phosphate group
Classified as liquid, but act differently from other lipiids
Include sex hormones and other hormones
Biochemical macromolecules involved with the transmission of inherited information
Two types of nucleic acids involved with inheritance
Five nucleotide bases found in nucleic acids (ACGT & U)
the fluid mosaic model of the structure of the plasma membrane and the movement of hydrophilic and hydrophobic substances across it based on their size and polarity
Need to ensure I understand what can cross the membrane
the role of different organelles including ribosomes, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus and associated vesicles in the export of a protein product from the cell through exocytosis
Sometimes confuse golgi apparatus and ER when looking at SEM images
cellular engulfment of material by endocytosis.
nucleic acids as information molecules that encode instructions for the synthesis of proteins in cells
Protein functional diversity and the nature of the proteome
Understand most of the terminology, though should revise.
the functional importance of the four hierarchal levels of protein structure
Should ensure that I answer related questions with the proper wording (Eg. regarding quaternary structure).
the synthesis of a polypeptide chain from amino acid monomers by condensation polymerisation
Can remember terminology, though need to ensure I am clear in my responses.
the structure of DNA and the three forms of RNA including similarities and differences in their subunits, and their synthesis by condensation polymerisation
Confident of role of tRNA, mRNA and rRNA
Should revise specific structural components and subunits of these molecules
the genetic code as a degenerate triplet code and the steps in gene expression including transcription, RNA processing in eukaryotic cells and translation.
the functional distinction between structural genes and regulatory genes
the structure of genes in eukaryotic cells including stop and start instructions, promoter regions, exons and introns
TODO: Add these to glossary with labelled diagram (Basic it off my labelled studysheet diagram)
use of the lac operon as a simple prokaryotic model that illustrates the switching off and on of genes by proteins (transcriptional factors) expressed by regulatory genes.
Structure and regulation of biochemical pathways
the role of enzymes as protein catalysts in biochemical pathways
Confident, though should ensure I consistently use vocab

the mode of action of enzymes including reversible and irreversible inhibition of their action due to chemical competitors at the active site, and by factors including temperature, concentration and pH
Confident that I understand how competitors work and the difference between competitive and non competitive
the cycling of coenzymes (ATP, NADH, and NADPH) as loaded and unloaded forms to move energy, protons and electrons between reactions in the cell.
however I need to clarify whether/if they clarify protons or electrons. At the moment, just think 'energy'
chloroplasts as the site of photosynthesis, an overview of their structure and evidence of their bacterial origins
, though should review specifics of bacterial origins
inputs and outputs of the light dependent and light independent (Calvin cycle) stages of photosynthesis in C3 plants (details of the biochemical pathway mechanisms are not required)
Mostly confident, but should continually recall over the course of the year to keep fresh
factors that affect the rate of photosynthesis, including light, temperature and carbon dioxide concentration.
Confident. In fact, should really just memorise so I nail the wording
the location of, and the inputs and outputs of, glycolysis including ATP yield (details of the biochemical pathway mechanisms are not required)
mitochondria as the site of aerobic cellular respiration, an overview of their structure and evidence of their bacterial origins
, though should review specifics of bacterial origins
the main inputs and outputs of the Krebs (citric acid) cycle and electron transport chain including ATP yield (details of the biochemical pathway mechanisms are not required)
Should review over the course of the year, though mostly confident. Remember, visually, where these inputs and outputs travel and what their job is.
the location of anaerobic cellular respiration, its inputs and the difference in outputs between animals and yeasts including ATP yield
factors that affect the rate of cellular respiration, including temperature, glucose availability and oxygen concentration
Review factors a little more, for everything really. Not too difficult, but easy to make silly mistakes with.
the sources and mode of transmission of various signalling molecules to their target cell, including plant and animal hormones, neurotransmitters, cytokines and pheromones
the stimulus-response model when applied to the cell in terms of signal transduction as a three-step process involving reception, transduction and cellular response

difference in signal transduction for hydrophilic and hydrophobic signals in terms of the position of receptors (on the membrane and in the cytosol) and initiation of transduction (details of specific chemicals, names of second messengers, G protein pathways, reaction mechanisms or cascade reactions are not required)

apoptosis as a natural, regulatory process of programmed cell death, initiated after a cell receives a signal from inside (mitochondrial pathway) or from outside (death receptor pathway) the cell resulting in the removal of cells that are no longer needed or that may be a threat to an organism, mediated by enzymes (caspases) that cleave specific proteins in the cytoplasm or nucleus (details of specific cytoplasmic or nuclear proteins are not required)
malfunctions in apoptosis that result in deviant cell behaviour leading to diseases including cancer.
an antigen as a unique molecule or part of a molecule that initiates an immune response including the distinction between non-self antigens, self-antigens and allergens

invading cellular and non-cellular pathogens as a source of non-self antigens, and preventative strategies including physical, chemical and microbiological barriers in animals and plants that keep them out

the characteristics and roles of components (macrophages, neutrophils, mast cells, dendritic cells, complement proteins) of the innate (non-specific) immune response to an antigen including the steps in the inflammatory response
Changes in the genetic makeup of a population

the qualitative treatment of the causes of changing allele frequencies in a population’s gene pool including types of mutations (point, frameshift, block) as a source of new alleles, chromosomal abnormalities (aneuploidy and polyploidy), environmental selection pressures on phenotypes as the mechanism for natural selection, gene flow, and genetic drift (bottleneck and founder effects) and the biological consequences of such changes in terms of increased or reduced genetic diversity

processes of evolution including through the action of mutations and different selection pressures on a fragmented population and subsequent isolating mechanisms (allopatric speciation) that prevent gene flow
the manipulation of gene pools through selective breeding programs.
significant changes in life forms in Earth’s geological history including the rise of multicellular organisms, animals on land, the first flowering plants and mammals

evidence of biological change over time including from palaeontology (the fossil record, the relative and absolute dating of fossils, types of fossils and the steps in fossilisation), biogeography, developmental biology and structural morphology
patterns of biological change over geological time including divergent evolution, convergent evolution and mass extinctions.
molecular homology as evidence of relatedness between species including DNA and amino acid sequences, mtDNA (the molecular clock) and the DNA hybridisation technique
the use of phylogenetic trees to show relatedness between species

the evolution of novel phenotypes arising from chance events within genomes, specifically sets of genes that regulate developmental processes and lead to changes in the expression of a few master genes found across the animal phyla, as demonstrated by the expression of gene BMP4 in beak formation of the Galapagos finches and jaw formation of cichlid fish in Africa.
shared characteristics that define primates, hominoids and hominins
major trends in hominin evolution from the genus Australopithecus to the genus Homo including structural, functional and cognitive changes and the consequences for cultural evolution

the human fossil record as an example of a classification scheme that is open to interpretations that are contested, refined or replaced when new evidence challenges them or when a new model has greater explanatory power, including whether Homo sapiens and Homo neanderthalensis interbred and the placement of the Denisovans into the Homo evolutionary tree.
the use of enzymes including endonucleases (restriction enzymes), ligases and polymerases
amplification of DNA using the polymerase chain reaction
the use of gel electrophoresis in sorting DNA fragments, including interpretation of gel runs
the use of recombinant plasmids as vectors to transform bacterial cells.
techniques that apply DNA knowledge (specifically gene cloning, genetic screening and DNA profiling) including social and ethical implications and issues

the distinction between genetically modified and transgenic organisms, their use in agriculture to increase crop productivity and to provide resistance to insect predation and/or disease, and the biological, social and ethical implications that are raised by their use

strategies that deal with the emergence of new diseases in a globally connected world, including the distinction between epidemics and pandemics, the use of scientific knowledge to identify the pathogen, and the types of treatments

the concept of rational drug design in terms of the complementary nature (shape and charge) of small molecules that are designed to bind tightly to target biomolecules (limited to enzymes) resulting in the enzyme’s inhibition and giving rise to a consequential therapeutic benefit, illustrated by the Australian development of the antiviral drug Relenza as a neuraminidase inhibitor
the use of chemical agents against pathogens including the distinction between antibiotics and antiviral drugs with reference to their mode of action and biological effectiveness.
the biological concepts specific to the investigation and their significance, including definitions of key terms, and biological representations

the characteristics of scientific research methodologies and techniques of primary qualitative and quantitative data collection relevant to the selected investigation, including laboratory work (biochemistry, cytology, immunology) and/or fieldwork (geomorphology); precision, accuracy, reliability and validity of data; and minimisation of experimental bias
ethics and issues of research including identification and application of relevant health, safety and bioethical guidelines
methods of organising, analysing and evaluating primary data to identify patterns and relationships including sources of error and limitations of data and methodologies
models, theories and classification keys, and their use in organising and explaining observed phenomena and biological concepts including their limitations
the nature of evidence that supports or refutes a hypothesis, model or theory
the key findings of the selected investigation and their relationship to cytological, biochemical and/or evolutionary concepts

the conventions of scientific report writing and scientific poster presentation including biological terminology and representations, standard abbreviations, units of measurement and acknowledgment of references
Multicellular organisms have developed mechanisms to comunicate between cells and convey messages about changes to internal and external environment conditions
Effector cells respond to signalling molecules.
Mode of transmission of signalling molecules
Autocrine: A cell targets itself. Eg - Activated T Lymphocytes produce a cytokine for which they also have receptors for.
Paracrine: A cell targets a nearby cell. Eg - Neurotransmitters are secreted by a neuron and target the next neuron in the neural pathway.

Endocrine: A cell targets a distant cell through the bloodstream. Eg - Animal hormones are released from glands and organs and through throughout the body, usually in the bloodstream, to act on distant target cells.
Nature and source of signalling molecules
Classified according to chemical properties as hydrophobic or hydrophillic.
Signalling molecule produced in tiny amounts that can have relatively long last effects on targets cells. Regulate the growth and activity of cells in most animals and plants.
In vertebrates, the endocrine is response for coordinating many body functions, including growth, metabolism and reproduction.
Hormones can be grouped into three main classes:

Lipid hormones are hydrophobic, ad derived from fatty acids or cholesterol. Include steroid hormones which regulate metabolism, salt and water balance, etc. Examples of steroid hormones include the sex hormones.
Peptide and protein hormones: Class of hydrophillic signalling molecules. Example is insulin, and an example of a protein hormone is a growth horomne.
Amino-acid-derived hormones are a class of small signalling molecules derived from amino acids tyrosine and tryptophan. Some hydrophobic (thyroid hormones), some hydrophillic (catecholammines)
Visible effect: Seed and bud dormancy, drought tolerance and apical dominance.
Visible effect: Shoot tip bends towards the light (phototropism), roots grow downwards (gravitropism), apical dominance
Visible effect: Growth of lateral branches
Visible effect: Increases sugar content of fruit, fruit and leaf drop
Visible effect: Elongation of stems, leaf expansion, seed fermination, fruit and flower maturation.
Group of hydrophillic signalling molecules secret by neurons.
Neurotransmitters are produced in the synaptic terminals of the neuron.
Mode of transmission: Form of paracrine signalling.

Neurons secrete neurotransmitters into specialised junctions they form with local target cells, such as other neurons, gland cells or muslce cells. The jungles are called synapses. When an electrical signal arrives, it triggers the release of neurotransmitters into the intersynaptic space. The neurotransmitters diffuse across the intersynaptic space and bind to receptors on the surface of the postsynaptic neuron, which will in turn cause the transmission of the nerveous impulse from one neuron to another.

Group of hydrophillic signalling molecules involved in communication between immune cells. Cytokines coordinate many aspects of the immune response and are released by body cells in response to damage or pathogens. Sources of cytokines include macrophages, T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes. Some cytokines, such as interferones and interleukins, are primarily involved in regulating inflammation and other immune system responses to infection.
Signalling molecules that are excreted into the external environment of the organism are called pheromones. Usually influence the behaviour of another individual, usually of the same species.
Common functions in animals include triggering alarm and aggressive responses, marking territory, marking food trails and attracting mates.
The process of converting an original stimulus signal into a response. Involves changing the form of the signal in some way.
Two general, characteristic types of signal transduction are hydrophobic and hydrophilic.
Cells in a multicellular organisms must communicate with each other.
Three step: Reception by a receptor, transduction, and cellular response.
In transduction, multistep sequential activation of different molecules in a chain of events are called cascades.
The response may occur in the nucleus, cytosol, or plasma membrane.
Usually lipid based molecules involved in gene regulation.
Lipid soluble so they can easily diffuse through the plasma membrane

Steroid hormones are examples of lipid based hydrophobic signalling molecules that bind to receptors in the cyytosol. Once bound, the signalling molecule-receptor complex moves from the cytosol through nuclear pores to the final destination in the nucleus.
Steroid hormones includes the sex hormones (testosterone, estrogen, etc), cortisol, aidosterone, vitamin D.
Once in the nucleus, sig molecule receptor complex acts as
Include hydrophilic peptides hormones, neurotransmitters, and cytokines.

Water soluble, and so are unable to diffuse through plasma membranes. Therefore, the first step for all hydrophilic signalling molecules is to interact with the receptors on the external surface of the plasma membrane.

The receptors for these signalling molecules are transmembrane proteins, which are made up of oe of more protein molecules and span both layers of the plasma membrane. An example of a transmembrane protein is the G=protein coupled receptor, which consists of seven membrane spanning domains. The receptor is activated by the ind of molecules on the surface of the cell to induce cellular responses inside the cell.
The receptor may initiate a cellular response directly or indirectly by the activation of other molecules such as second messenges g proteins, or both.
Second messengers: Intermediate signalling molecules that relay signals.
A signalling molecules an initiate different responses in different cell types
Different receptors for th same sig molecule can exist in different cells, which may activate different transduction cascades.
Proteins can be specific to particular cells and will lead to a particular response only in the cells in which they are present.
A cascade in a transduction pathway allows the
Responses in the cytosol cause the inhibition or activation of enzymes, which control cellular functions. Insulin is one hormone that acts on enzymes in the cytosol of target cells.
Some ion channels can be opened or closed in response to cellular signals.

Upon stimulation, gated sodium and potassium ion channels on the neurons surface are opened. Sudden movement of the ions into and out of neuron initiates the action potential, which travels the length of the axon of the neuron in a wave like sequence, opening other ion channels along the membrane.
Programmed cell death. All or nothing process, one triggered, cannot be stopped.
Apoptosis is a receptor mediated response triggered by signalling molecules inside or outside the cell. Causes include cell aging, cell obsolescence (lack of requirement) and damaged DNA.
Once signaled, apoptosis occurs as a series of coordinated steps.
Caspases and the process of apoptosis

Enzymes called caspases are responsible for apoptosis. They are produced within the cell and stored as inactive precursors. When a sig. molecule is produced to stimulate apoptosis the sig molecule binds to a receptor and this binding activates the caspase precursor. This then stimulated the activation of other caspases, triggering a cascade that leads to cell death.
Caspace-3 is a protease that plays a role in apoptosis. It causes theg radmentation of actin gilaments, part of a cell's cytoskeleton, and the inactivation of DNA repair.
Budding of plama membrane bound bescicles called apoptic bodies which prevent toxic or ummunogenic substances from leaking when the apoptic bodies are phagocytosed.
Phagocytosis of the apoptic bodies by specialised cells, typically macrophages, without spilling cell contents or triggering an inflammatory response.
Two major pathways on the basis of where the signal comes from - inside (intrinsic) or outside (extrinsic)
The intrinsic pathway is also referred to as the mitochondrial pathway
The extrinsic pathway is also referred to as the death receptor pathway.
